questions.question:
Question 1: A patient describes the image below on the Amsler grid test. In which of the given conditions 
is this phenomenon noted?
questions.explanation:
The image shows metamorphopsia seen in posterior uveitis. Metamorphopsia is a condition in which patients perceive distorted images of the object. It is 
measured using the Amsler grid, which tests the central 10 degrees of vision. In posterior uveitis, 
metamorphopsia occurs due to macular edema. Posterior uveitis is a painless inflammation of the choroid. Patients present with various visual 
symptoms like defective vision, black spots floating in front of the eye, micropsia/macropsia and 
positive scotomas.

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following features is unlikely to be noted in a patient with 
Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Iris heterochromia is not a feature of Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome. Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome is an idiopathic, multi-system disorder characterised by 
autoimmunity against melanocytes. It is associated with HLA-DR1 and HLA-DR4 across different 
racial groups. 356 
Sold by @itachibot Patients may present with cutaneous, neurological and ocular features. Cutaneous features 
include alopecia, poliosis and vitiligo (option A). Neurological features include meningism, 
encephalopathy, tinnitus, deafness and vertigo (option B). Ocular features include bilateral 
chronic granulomatous panuveitis (option C), posterior uveitis, exudative retinal detachment, 
perilimbal vitiligo (Suguiura's sign) and sunset glow appearance of the fundus. The modified diagnostic criteria for Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada syndrome are as follows: • Absence of a history of penetrating ocular trauma • Absence of other ocular disease entities • Bilateral uveitis • Neurological and auditory manifestations • Integumentary findings, not preceding the onset of the central nervous system or ocular 
diseases, such as alopecia, poliosis, and vitiligo. The treatment is high-dose (1–2 mg/kg/day) oral prednisolone, tapered over 3–6 months. This may 
be preceded by intravenous methylprednisolone pulse therapy (500–1000 mg/day).

questions.question:
Question 3: 350 
Sold by @itachibot A middle aged male presents with recurrent oral ulcers and ulcers over his scrotum. He also 
has pain and redness of both his eyes. A positive pathergy test is noted. What is the HLA 
association of the disease this patient is most likely to be suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Recurrent oral ulcers, ulcers over his scrotum with binocular pain and redness and a positive 
pathergy test point to a diagnosis of Behcet's disease. HLA B5 (HLA B51) is associated with 
Behcet's disease. Behcet's disease is a systemic vasculitis that can cause recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, skin 
lesions and ocular inflammation. Pathergy test is usually positive. Ocular inflammation occurs in 
about 70% of patients and tends to be more severe in men. A classical presentation is 
relapsing/remitting acute onset panuveitis with retinal vasculitis which resolves spontaneously 
even without treatment. It is usually bilateral and non-granulomatous. Patients present with a 
transient mobile hypopyon in a relatively white eye. They may develop visual impairment if retinal 
vascular disease (vasculitis and occlusion) occurs. Other options: Option A: HLA-B27 is associated with Reiter's syndrome. Option B: HLA DR1 and HLA-DR4 are associated with Vogt–Koyanagi–Haradas disease. Option D: HLA Bw54 is associated with Possner–Scholssman syndrome. Note: The association between HLA-A29 and birdshot retinochoroidopathy is the most consistent 
of any medical disorder. Approximately 95% of patients with birdshot retinochoroidopathy are 
HLA-A29–positive.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 28 year old man presents to the medicine OPD with cough with hemoptysis of 1 month 
duration. A sputum culture done is shown below. What is the most common ocular 
manifestation associated with this infection?
questions.explanation:
The image shows the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) colonies on the 
Lowenstein-Jensen medium. In tuberculosis (TB), granulomatous panuveitis is the most common 357 
Sold by @itachibot ocular feature. Ocular TB commonly occurs due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB. It can have 
multiple presentations like lupus vulgaris of eyelid, tubercular conjunctivitis, interstitial keratitis, 
granulomatous uveitis and endophthalmitis. Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis is caused by a 
hypersensitivity reaction to the MTB antigen. Treatment of granulomatous panuveitis is anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) plus steroids.

questions.question:
Question 5: In a patient showing salt and pepper appearance of the fundus, which of the following is not a 
differential diagnosis? 351 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Salt and pepper fundus is not seen in tuberculosis. Salt and pepper fundus is seen when there are multiple small black and white spots present on the 
retina. It is also known as pseudo-retinitis pigmentosa. Its causes include congenital syphilis, 
rubella, Refsum’s disease, carriers of albinism, Leber’s congenital amaurosis and retinitis 
pigmentosa sine pigmentosa.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 32-year-old lady presented with dry, itchy eyes, blurred vision, and sensitivity to light. She 
says there are black dots floating around in her visual field. She denies wearing any spectacles 
or contact lenses. On fundoscopy, the following image is obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Dry, itchy eyes, blurred vision, sensitivity to light with candle wax dripping on fundus 
examination points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a chronic granulomatous multi-system disease. Ocular inflammation occurs in 25–
70% of sarcoid patients, which includes uveitis, conjuctival and lacrimal gland involvement. 
Chronic granulomatous panuveitis may be seen. Anterior uveitis is the most common 
manifestation. In anterior uveitis due to sarcoidosis, "mutton fat" keratic precipitates (KPs) and/or small 
granulomatous KPs with iris nodules (Koeppe and/or Busacca) are seen. Trabecular meshwork 
(TM) nodules and/or tent-shaped peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) is also seen. 358 
Sold by @itachibot In intermediate uveitis, vitreous cells with snowbanking and snowball opacities/string of pearl 
appearance are seen. Posterior uveitis presents with candle-wax dripping (thick venous sheathing 
and periphlebitis), pre-retinal nodules (Lander’s sign), choroidal granulomata and sarcoid 
infiltration. Other ocular features seen are interstitial keratitis and band-shaped 
keratopathy. Steroids are the mainstay of treatment in sarcoidosis.

questions.question:
Question 7: What is the most common ocular manifestation in patients infected by the human 
immunodeficiency virus?
questions.explanation:
Microangiopathy is the most common ocular feature of HIV infection. Microangiopathy of the retina in HIV consists of the hemorrhages, micro-aneurysms and 
cotton-wool spots or soft exudates (axonal debris). Cotton wool spots are the most common 
finding of HIV retinopathy. HIV leads to multiple opportunistic infections of the eye like cytomegalovirus (CMV) - most 
common cause of posterior uveitis in HIV - toxoplasmosis, Pneumocystis carinii and herpes 
zoster. These infections present as keratitis, choroiditis, retinitis and endophthalmitis. The most common ocular adverse effect in patients receiving highly active antiretroviral therapy 
(HAART) is immune recovery uveitis (IRU). It is a non-granulomatous uveitis (usually anterior 
uveitis and vitritis) associated with a paradoxical or exaggerated reactivation of the immune 
system and an increase in intraocular inflammation. It occurs after receiving HAART for CMV 
chorioretinitis. Visual complications of IRU include cataract, cystoid macular edema (CME), 
glaucoma, and epiretinal membrane formation.

questions.question:
Question 8: An HIV positive patient presented to OPD with painless blurring of vision. On fundus 
examination, the following findings were seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Painless blurring of vision in an HIV positive patient with "sauce and cheese" or "pizza pie" 
retinopathy (shown in the image) is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. 359 
Sold by @itachibot CMV retinitis is the most common ocular opportunistic infection in patients with HIV. It is often 
asymptomatic and can be classified as central or peripheral CMV retinitis. Central CMV retinitis is 
characterised by dense, white areas of retinal necrosis and retinal hemorrhage in the areas of 
necrosis - pizza pie or sauce and cheese appearance. Peripheral CMV retinitis is less demarcated. The infection spreads along the vascular arcades in a 
brush fire-like fashion.

questions.question:
Question 9: A newly diagnosed HIV-positive lady with CD4+ count of 35/L presented with decreased 
visual acuity and floaters. On fundus examination, there were dense, white areas of retinal 
necrosis with interspersed areas of retinal hemorrhage. What is the most rapid and accurate 
method to confirm the diagnosis?

options.c: Viral nucleic acid detection in intraocular fluid
options.d: Viral antibody detection in blood by ELISA

questions.explanation:
An HIV-positive patient with CD4+ count of 35/L presenting with decreased visual acuity, 
floaters and pizza pie retinitis (dense, white areas of retinal necrosis with interspersed areas of 
retinal hemorrhage) likely has CMV retinitis. The most rapid and accurate method to diagnose 
cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is viral nucleic acid detection in the intraocular fluid. CMV retinitis is an opportunistic infection seen in HIV patients with a CD4+ count less than 
50/L. Patients present with reduced vision due to macular involvement and floaters due to 
vitritis. One eye is usually affected initially. Retinitis is seen. Frosted branch angiitis (FBA), which 
is marked vascular sheathing that occurs in about 6% patients, may be seen. Cataract is common 
late-stage manifestation of CMV retinitis. Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the mainstay of management, restoring the 
patient’s innate ability to suppress CMV activity. Valganciclovir is a prodrug of ganciclovir that is 
taken orally. Ganciclovir slow-release intravitreal implant can also be used. Screening of patients with low CD4+ counts: • 3-monthly, if <50/l • 6-monthly, if 50–100/l • Yearly, if >100/l

questions.question:
Question 10: A 32-year-old man presented with blurring of vision in the right eye. Examination reveals 
mild iritis, severe vitritis, and a focal necrotic lesion on the macula. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Monocular iritis, severe vitritis with a focal necrotic lesion on the macula is a classical description 
of ocular toxoplasmosis. Ocular toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular protozoan. It 
causes severe recurrent attacks of posterior uveitis in adults, due to reactivation at previously 
inactive cyst-containing scars. A single inflammatory focus of fluffy white retinitis or 
retinochoroiditis associated with a pigmented scar ("satellite lesion") is typical. "Headlight in the 
fog" is the classic description of a white retinal inflammatory nidus viewed through 
vitritis. "Spill-over" anterior uveitis is common. Treatment: • Prednisolone (1 mg/kg) is given initially and tapered according to clinical response. • Pyrimethamine is administered as a loading dose of 75–100 mg for 1–2 days followed by 25–50 
mg daily for 4 weeks in combination with oral folinic (not folic) acid 5 mg three times a week to 360 
Sold by @itachibot retard thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and folate deficiency. • Sulfadiazine 1 g four times daily for 3–4 weeks is usually given in combination with 
pyrimethamine. • Intravitreal therapy with clindamycin (1 mg) and dexamethasone (400 g) may be as effective as 
triple therapy in reactivated infection. The image shows the characteristic "headlight in the fog" appearance:

questions.question: Question 11: In which disease is the "headlight in fog" appearance seen?
questions.explanation:
The "headlight in fog" appearance is seen in toxoplasmosis. Ocular toxoplasmosis presents with iridocyclitis, which can be granulomatous or 
non-granulomatous. There is focal superficial necrotizing retinochoroiditis along with vitritis, 
which gives the "headlight in fog" appearance (image). Fundoscopy shows deep retinitis and 
papillitis with granulomas. Old choroid lesions of toxoplasmosis are punched-out lesions with 
pigmented borders. The treatment of choice for ocular toxoplasmosis is triple therapy with systemic steroids, 
pyrimethamine, and sulfadiazine. Clindamycin is also used. 361 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 45-year-old man presented with red-eye, ocular pain, and acute loss of vision to the 
casualty. On fundoscopy, areas of retinal ischemia and necrosis were seen, leading to a 
diagnosis of acute retinal necrosis. Which of the following statements is false regarding this 
condition?

options.b: It is seen in immunocompetent individuals.
options.c: Posterior pole is involved initially with centrifugal spread.
options.d: It may lead to retinal detachment.

questions.explanation:
In acute retinal necrosis, the posterior pole is typically spared until late. Acute retinal necrosis (ARN) occurs in immunocompetent individuals. It is a severe posterior 
uveitis causing retinal necrosis. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is the most common cause of acute 
retinal necrosis in adults. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) are the 
commonest causes of acute retinal necrosis in children. Patients present with confluent peripheral necrotizing retinitis, retinal arteritis with 
vaso-occlusion, and vitritis. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachments are common due to retinal 
thinning from large areas of necrosis. The posterior pole is involved only in the later stages. Aciclovir is administered intravenously (10 mg/kg, every 8 hours) for 10–14 days, and then orally 
(800 mg, five times daily) for 6–12 weeks. Oral valaciclovir or famciclovir may be substituted for 
oral aciclovir, with similar outcomes but better tolerability. Intravitreal ganciclovir or foscarnet 
may enhance the prognosis. Systemic steroids may be started 24 hours after the initiation of 
antiviral therapy, especially in severe cases. Laser retinopexy is performed around necrotic areas. Progressive outer retinal necrosis is a manifestation of HSV or varicella zoster virus (VZV) that 
occurs in immunocompromised individuals. It may begin at the posterior pole or the periphery. It 
has a rapid course and is not generally associated with vasculitis.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 65-year-old male presents with a painful decrease in vision of his right eye for the past 3 
days. He underwent right phacoemulsification with PC-IOL insertion 6 months ago. 
Examination revealed a mild granulomatous anterior uveitis with minimal hypopyon and 
mild vitritis. There is a white plaque seen on the posterior lens capsule. Which one of the 354 
Sold by @itachibot following is the most appropriate therapy for this condition?

options.a: Vitrectomy and intravitreal injection of amphotericin B
options.c: Vitrectomy, removal of the IOL, and intravitreal injection of gentamicin
options.d: Vitrectomy, posterior capsulotomy, and intravitreal injection of vancomycin

questions.explanation:
Painful decrease in vision following cataract surgery 6 months ago with granulomatous anterior 
uveitis, hypopyon, vitritis and a white plaque on the posterior lens capsule suggests a diagnosis of 
delayed-onset postoperative endophthalmitis caused by Propionibacterium acnes. The best 
management for the above clinical scenario would be vitrectomy and posterior capsulotomy, 
followed by intravitreal injection of vancomycin. 362 
Sold by @itachibot Delayed-onset endophthalmitis, a complication of cataract surgery, has a slow course and 
panuveitis like picture. There is low grade anterior chamber inflammation and vitritis. When 
caused by P. acnes, it typically presents from 3 months to 2 years after surgery with a 
characteristic white retro-lenticular plaque on the posterior capsule of lens. Endophthalmitis 
caused by Candida occurs within 3 months of surgery. Management includes anterior vitrectomy, IOL explantation, posterior capsulectomy, intravitreal 
vancomycin, and a scleral-fixated intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.

questions.question:
Question 14: Sympathetic ophthalmia is seen after  
.
questions.explanation:
Sympathetic ophthalmia is seen after a penetrating trauma. Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating trauma 
or less frequently, following intraocular surgery, usually multiple vitreoretinal procedures. 
Patients present between 2 weeks and 3 months after initial injury. The earliest symptom is blurred near vision in the sympathizing (uninjured) eye. The earliest sign 
is a retrolental flare in the sympathizing eye. Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes. The fundus 
shows multifocal choroidal infiltrates in the mid-periphery. Sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) 
infiltrates corresponding to Dalen–Fuchs nodules (image)(a granuloma situated between Bruch 
membrane and the RPE) are also present. Steroids are the basis of treatment. High-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months. 
Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate can be used in 
resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents. Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual 
potential within 2 weeks of injury prevents the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

questions.question: Question 15: What is the most common cause of endophthalmitis in a patient following eye trauma?
questions.explanation:
363 
Sold by @itachibot Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of post-traumatic endophthalmitis, 
followed by Bacillus cereus. However, if the trauma involves soil contamination, Bacillus cereus is the most common cause of 
post-traumatic endophthalmitis.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following drugs should not be used in a patient with uveitis and raised IOP?
questions.explanation:
Pilocarpine should not be used in cases of uveitis with raised intraocular pressure. Hypertensive uveitis or inflammatory glaucoma occurs when uveitis is associated with raised IOP. 
It is treated with topical cycloplegics (atropine), topical steroids and IOP-lowering drugs like 
topical timolol or systemic acetazolamide. Pilocarpine is contraindicated since it causes miosis 
and ciliary spasm. It also increases intraocular inflammation. 364 
Sold by @itachibot Disorders of the Eyelid
